links.title: QBE - Compiler Backend
links.description:
QBE aims to be a pure C embeddable backend that provides 70%
of the performance of advanced compilers in 10% of the code.  Its
small size serves both its aspirations of correctness and our
ability to understand, fix, and improve it.  It also serves its
users by providing trivial integration and great flexibility.

Code
 git clone git://c9x.me/qbe.git
 QBE is known to compile and pass its test suite on the following
x64 operating systems.

Linux
...

links.title: QBE vs LLVM
links.description:
Both QBE and LLVM are compiler backends using an SSA
representation.  This document will explain why LLVM
does not make QBE a redundant project.  Obviously,
everything following is biased, because written by me.

links.title: Crafting Interpreters

This book contains everything you need to implement a full-featured,
efficient scripting language. You‚Äôll learn both high-level concepts around
parsing and semantics and gritty details like bytecode representation and
garbage collection. Your brain will light up with new ideas, and your hands will
get dirty and calloused. It‚Äôs a blast.

Nix is a purely functional package manager.
This means that it treats packages like values in purely functional
programming languages such as Haskell ‚Äî they are built by functions
that don‚Äôt have side-effects, and they never change after they have
been built.  Nix stores packages in the Nix
store, usually the directory
/nix/store, where each package has its own unique
subdirectory such as
